'''Oskar Johann Viktor Anderson''' ({{lang-be|Оскар Віктар Андэрсан}}; 2 August 1887, [[Minsk]], [[Russian Empire]] – 12 February 1960, [[Munich]], [[Germany]]) was a [[Germany|German]]-[[Russia]]n [[mathematician]]. He was most famously known for his work on [[mathematical statistics]].

== Life ==
Anderson was born from a [[Baltic German|German]] family in [[Minsk]] (now in [[Belarus]]), but soon moved to [[Kazan]] ([[Russia]]). His father, [[Nikolai Anderson]], was professor in [[Finno-Ugric languages]] at the [[University of Kazan]]. His older brothers were the [[folklorist]] [[Walter Anderson (folklorist)|Walter Anderson]] and the [[astrophysicist]] [[Wilhelm Anderson]]. Oskar Anderson graduated from [[Kazan Gymnasium]] with a gold medal in 1906. After studying [[mathematics]] for one year at the [[University of Kazan]], he moved to [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]] to study [[economics]] at the [[Saint Petersburg Polytechnical University|Polytechnic Institute]]. From 1907 to 1915, he was [[Alexander Alexandrovich Chuprov|Aleksandr Chuprov's]] assistant. In 1912 he started lecturing at a commercial school in [[St. Petersburg]]. In 1918 he took on a professorship in [[Kiev]] but he was forced to flee [[Russia]] in 1920 due to the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian Revolution]], first taking a post in [[Budapest]] ([[Hungary]]) before becoming a professor at the [[University of Economics Varna|University of Economics]] at [[Varna]] ([[Bulgaria]]) in 1924.
 
Anderson was one of the charter members of the [[Econometric Society]],<ref name="statprob">{{cite encyclopedia
  | last = Seneta 
  | first = Eugene William
  | title = Oskar Anderson
  | encyclopedia = StatProb: The Encyclopedia Sponsored by Statistics and Probability Societies
  | url = http://statprob.com/encyclopedia/OskarANDERSON.html
  | publisher = Springer Science+Business Media, LLC
  | year = 2010
 }}</ref> whose members also elected him to be a fellow of the society in 1933.<ref>{{cite web | title=In Memoriam | work=List of Deceased Fellows of the Econometric Society | url=http://www.econometricsociety.org/inmemoriam.asp| accessdate=December 1, 2012}}</ref>

In 1935 he was appointed director of the Statistical Institute for Economic Research at the [[Sofia University|University of Sofia]] and in 1942 he took up a full professorship of statistics at the [[University of Kiel]], where he was joined by his brother [[Walter Anderson (folklorist)|Walter Anderson]] after the end of the second world war. In 1947 he took a position at the [[Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich|University of Munich]], teaching there until 1956, when he retired.

== Writings ==
* ''Über die repräsentative Methode und deren Anwendung auf die Aufarbeitung der Ergbnisse der bulgarischen landwirtschaftlichen Betriebszählung vom 31. Dezember 1926'', München : Bayer. Statist. Landesamt, 1949
* ''Die Saisonschwankungen in der deutschen Stromproduktion vor und nach dem Kriege '', München : Inst. f. Wirtschaftsforschung, 1950
